	<item>

	<item>
		<title>Welcome</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Mar 2012 03:55:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/?page_id=2</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/red-arrow-logo.png"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-495" title="Red Arrow Logo" src="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/red-arrow-logo.png?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="200" /></a>Red Arrow Media is a company of media professionals. From the first typed word to the final designed form ready for print, we offer authors a self-service bar full of menu options to compose, produce, print, and distribute their work of art.

We specialize in helping "budding" authors as well as seasoned writers find their unique voice, write and edit their works, and create an aesthetically pleasing interior and exterior design. We also serve as a "middleman" to a plethora of other media services from printing &amp; distribution to bookselling, website development, publicity campaigns, photography, and video production.

Since our staff is rather cosmopolitan and comprised of various nationalities (English, Australian, and North American, to be specific), we each bring a world of varied experience to the table. We uniteÂ in our desire to create, produce, and distribute excellent literary text and various forms of media across the globe. Our vision is to grow and expand into a media company that not only produces literature, but also photographic journals and video documentaries that keep our audiences apprised of current social trends and social justice issues.

<a href="mailto:customercare@redarrowmedia.com">Email</a> Red Arrow Media.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-03-19 03:55:03</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-03-19 03:55:03</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>about</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Renee Evans</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/renee-evans/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 26 Mar 2012 22:10:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/?page_id=458</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[RenÃ©e (short for Renaissance) Evans works as a freelance format designer, based in Redding California. Before moving to California 3.5 years ago RenÃ©e was the acquisitions/production manager of a book publishing company located in her hometown of Sydney Australia. Renee works with authors who desire to create a product that is infused with passion, relevance, creativity and excellence. Having had the responsibility to manage an author through every stage of publishing, from manuscript reviews to design to marketing she has experience in the full publishing process.

RenÃ©e married Joaquin Evans in 2011 and they now travel the world together to places where people desire to see what Jesus is doing in the 21st Century. She loves the freedom that freelance works gives, enabling her to live both her passions for travel and for the written word. Her workspace is often a tray table, 30,000 feet off the ground.

RenÃ©e is passionate about revival, family, fun, food, great shoes, art, adventure and so much more. One of her favorite quotes to say is that she gets paid to do what she would do for free.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Renee Evans</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/about/renee-evans/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 26 Mar 2012 22:55:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/?page_id=460</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/renee-bio-1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-461" title="Renee in Chico, California" src="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/renee-bio-1.jpg" alt="" width="614" height="324" /></a>

RenÃ©e Evans works as a freelance format designer, based in Redding California. Before moving to California 3.5 years ago RenÃ©e was the acquisitions/production manager of a book publishing company located in her hometown of Sydney Australia. Renee works with authors who desire to create a product that is infused with passion, relevance, creativity and excellence. Having had the responsibility to manage an author through every stage of publishing, from manuscript reviews to design to marketing she has experience in the full publishing process.

<a href="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/renee-bio-2.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-462" title="Renee with husband Joaquin" src="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/renee-bio-2.jpg?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="227" /></a>RenÃ©e married Joaquin Evans in 2011 and they now travel the world together to places where people desire to see what Jesus is doing in the 21st Century. She loves the freedom that freelance works gives, enabling her to live both her passions for travel and for the written word. Her workspace is often a tray table, 30,000 feet off the ground.

She is passionate about revival, family, fun, food, great shoes, art, adventure and so much more. One of her favorite quotes to say is that she gets paid to do what she would do for free.

RenÃ©e is a Co-founder of Red Arrow Media, and manages social media and book design. Follow her blog:Â <a href="http://homeandinbetween.com/" target="_blank">http://homeandinbetween.com/</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Red Arrow Services</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/red-arrow-services/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 26 Mar 2012 23:18:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/?page_id=475</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center"><a href="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/arrow-logo1.png"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-476" title="Arrow Logo" src="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/arrow-logo1.png?w=150" alt="" width="150" height="100" /></a>Perhaps you are an aspiring author. Perhaps you have already accomplished much in the world of writing, but are looking for a new mode of publishing. Or perhaps you have a burning desire to share the story youâve created, but donât want to follow the traditional publishing route.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;">With the myriad of self-publishing venues available, larger and more traditional publishing houses are losing traction. Not only that, but even if you are offered a contract, they will do little more than slap their label on your book and display it in a catalog. No personal relationship. No walking out the journey with you. No marketing. No guarantee of success. You are on your own.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;">On one hand, that bit of information offers hope to those who want to self-publish! On the other hand, letâs say you do self-publish. You will have to figure out everything you need to know about the publishing world on your own, as a rookie. Who will help you? Once your work is finished, what will ensure that your work will be marketed? And most importantly, how do you know that your product is <em>excellent</em>?</p>
<p style="text-align:left;">Our <strong>writers and editors</strong> are professionals who have worked with names such as: William P. Young, author of <em>The Shack; </em>Mike Frank, author of <em>Prosperity with Purpose;</em> and Bill Johnson, author of numerous books including <em>When Heaven Invades Earth</em>âall of whom have sold or are on their way to selling thousands, if not millions, of copies.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;">Our <strong>book management team</strong> will manage the smallest to the largest details of seeing your book go to print. Weâll save you time, money, and research by providing a bridge to all of the services you need, and we'll negotiate sales and distribution prices with our printing company and booksellers.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;">Our <strong>marketing team</strong> is the most important aspect of self-publishing. If the work is excellent, who will know unless it is marketed well? Our team will research and target the top 100 reviewers in your specialized area. Weâll negotiate with bloggers, use SEO techniques, and set up a social media marketing campaign and online advertisements that will send your book viral. If you choose to go a step farther and want a publicity campaign, we can help you with that, too.</p>
<a href="mailto:customercare@redarrowmedia.com">Email</a> Red Arrow Media.
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong><a href="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/arrow-logo1.png"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-476" title="Arrow Logo" src="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/arrow-logo1.png?w=150" alt="" width="150" height="100" /></a>What We Offer</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center">Tier 1</p>
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong>General Manuscript Review</strong>: If your manuscript is already complete, weâll give you <em>general</em> feedback on your entire manuscript. Weâll point out strong <em>and</em> weak areas, and weâll give you recommendations for how you can further develop it.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong>Content Review</strong>: Weâll give you <em>detailed</em> feedback on your entire manuscript. That means weâll highlight specific areas, give you constructive criticism on those areas, and <em>show</em> you how to develop your writing more.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center">Tier 2</p>
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong>Ghostwriting</strong>: Perhaps you have a beautiful story to tell, but little to no writing skills. Or your dilemma may be, âI donât have time.â Our professionals will take the time to interview you, meet with you, learn your âvoiceâ (so that it sounds like you), and write <em>for</em> you.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong>Editing</strong>: Hereâs where many writers need help. Youâve written your story, and you want to find out if itâs âgood.â Or you might know that itâs quality writing, but need assistance with grammar, sentence structure, and paragraph transition or development. Weâll take your words, add to them, and create a flow so that your story reads easily and reaches its desired effect.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center">Tier 3</p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center"><strong>Design, Permissions, ISBN/Barcode, &amp; Endorsements:</strong> The content is pristine, but now what? You need it to look beautiful inside and out. Our team of designers has successfully created unique and captivating designs for many authors and special events (even the Queenâs Tea Party at Buckingham Palace). Quite often we receive compliments about how âwonderfulâ a book is before readers have opened its cover. Weâll create a book cover and interior design that matches and highlights the theme of your content. After that is finished, weâll send out permissions to other publishing houses (if you have quoted anyone elseâs work), set your pricing, and purchase and register your ISBN and barcode. If youâd like us to, weâll create a summary presentation of your bookâs theme and chapters to ask for endorsements from influential people in your bookâs targeted sphere.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center">Tier 4</p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center"><strong>Printing &amp; Distribution:</strong> Your book looks, sounds, and feels excellent (at least on the computer screen). Not only will you need it printed in a way that displays its quality, but if you want to sell copies, youâll also need it distributed through major book distribution channels. Weâll negotiate the lowest price possible on your first and consecutive print runs. Our distributor will make book copies available on major trade outlets, including Baker and Taylor, Ingram, Barnes and Noble/BarnesandNoble.com, and Amazon.com, and provide orders to over 8,000 retailers, including:</p>

<ol style="text-align:left;">
	<li>Books a Million</li>
	<li>Hastings</li>
	<li>Select Media</li>
	<li>Brodart</li>
	<li>Follett Library and Higher Education</li>
	<li>BN College</li>
	<li>Bookazine</li>
	<li>Levy</li>
	<li>Anderson Merchandisers</li>
	<li>The News Groups</li>
	<li>Quality</li>
	<li>Unique</li>
	<li>New Leaf</li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong>Printing &amp; Distribution (eBook):</strong> For major eBook distributors, sales have decupled (ten times) in 2011. We suggest that you create an eBook simultaneous to your regular print copy. Through our eBook creator and distributor, your book will be released through over thirty eBook outlets in various formats including:</p>

<ol style="text-align:left;">
	<li>Mobi</li>
	<li>ePub</li>
	<li>PDF</li>
	<li>iPad</li>
	<li>Nook</li>
	<li>Kindle</li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center">Tier 5</p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center"><strong>Marketing: </strong>Most publishing companies will tell you that itâs up to the author to make sure his/her book creates momentum. Some say that the real work hasnât begun <em>until</em> the book is published. While those statements are somewhat true, thereâs a lot Red Arrow can do to help propel your book forward. Weâll send review books to top players in your sphere of influence, deliver press releases, strategize social media marketing techniques, and (based on your preference) provide you with optional campaign packages that include bookselling, publicity, blogging, and video promo/short viral videos.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong>Royalties:</strong> Whatâs the <strong>best news?</strong> Since youâll be paying for services up-front, once the book goes to print, youâll keep MOST of the profit! No small royalty checks. No further fees to Red Arrow. On average, an author makes anywhere from 12-18% royalty on the net price of books sold from traditional publishing companies. Thatâs barely any revenue. When checks come in from Red Arrowâs distribution channels, youâll make most of the net profit. Youâll quickly accumulate the money you initially invested on your project and much more.</p>
<p style="text-align:left;">Why does Red Arrow keep a small royalty percentage? After your first print run, we continue to manage your book printing, distribution, and accounting. This takes a lot of âmiddlemanâ time and effort, and youâd like Red Arrow to stay in business, right?</p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center"></p>

</div>
<p style="text-align:left;"><strong>
</strong></p>
<a href="mailto:customercare@redarrowmedia.com">Email</a> Red Arrow Media.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>475</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>

		<wp:post_name>red-arrow-services</wp:post_name>

		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Why Red Arrow?</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/why-red-arrow/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 26 Mar 2012 23:21:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/?page_id=478</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><a href="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/arrow-logo1.png"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-476" title="Arrow Logo" src="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/arrow-logo1.png?w=150" alt="" width="150" height="100" /></a>Why Red Arrow?</strong>

Hereâs an overview of how we are <strong>different</strong> from every other publishing venue out there:
<ol>
	<li>We build a <strong>personal relationship</strong> with you, the author. This is your story, your dream, your âbabyâ (so to speak), and if you find that we are a good fit for you, weâll be on this journey with you, step by step, from start to finish.</li>
	<li>We guarantee <strong>excellence</strong>. We will spend the time and energy to ensure that your book is the best possible version of itself. Traditional publishing companies typically formulate your book into their persona, leaving little room to keep it in your own voice and style. Most self-publishing services do nothing to guarantee that your book has had enough edits, that the graphics are attractive and sellable, or that every minute detail of your book has been analyzed and approved as excellent. Because Red Arrow offers to walk your book journey with you, we wonât release it until we are <em>both</em> satisfied with its quality.</li>
	<li>We are <strong>passionate</strong> about what we do. As mentioned previously, we are a team of professionals who desire to see quality text created, produced, and effectively marketed worldwide. We are no small dreamersâwe have surrendered our work lives to conquer the seemingly âinsurmountableâ quest of fine literature. But we donât just want people to be appeased by our talent. Weâd like our target readers to experience a positive, transformative change through our literary texts.</li>
	<li>We want to see authors <strong>represented well,</strong> and we want to see them reach their <strong>full potential</strong>. If you were to chat with a Fortune 50 entrepreneur, they would tell you that they âare in the business of making money.â So are we, and you should be as well. However, we donât let money dictate our decisions. We choose our clients, just like you choose a publishing company that best fits your needs. We invest in authors who have a unique message. Too many books say the same thing. We look for an author who has a unique selling point, and once weâve decided to go on your book journey with you, we invest our time into <em>you</em>, not just your product.</li>
</ol>
<a href="mailto:customercare@redarrowmedia.com">Email</a> Red Arrow Media.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>478</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-03-26 23:21:04</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>

	<item>
		<title>Contact</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/contact/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 01 Apr 2012 16:26:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/?page_id=581</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/arrow-logo.png"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-582" title="Arrow Logo" src="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/arrow-logo.png?w=150" alt="" width="150" height="100" /></a>Red Arrow Media is located where the white-capped mountains meet the clear blue sky in northern California.

If you'd like to make personal contact or find out more information about our services, write us at: customercare@redarrowmedia.com.

You can also click on any one of our staff pages (under "Meet the Staff!" in the Categories Menu on the left side of the page) and email us individually.

We hope you return to our site soon!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Olivia LaField</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/books-authors-2/books-authors/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Apr 2012 18:03:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/?page_id=601</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/dsc_13452.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-621" title="DSC_1345" src="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/dsc_13452.jpg" alt="" width="238" height="360" /></a>

<a href="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/arrow-logo.png"><img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-582" title="Arrow Logo" src="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/arrow-logo.png?w=150" alt="" width="150" height="100" /></a><strong>2012 Northstate Educator of the Year</strong>

Olivia LaField, master public school educator for over thirty-five years and avid proponent of the Whole Child philosophy of education, believes that by meeting the social, emotional, and moral needs of our students, we meet their intellectual needs to substantially greater degrees. Her primary focus on the importance of building strong personal relationships with her students as well as her unique strategies for creating a mutually-respectful, self-directed classroom of independent learners have earned her several awards, including the 2006 Wells Fargo Legacy Teacher of the Year, and the 2012 California League of Middle Schools Northstate Educator of the Year. Ms. LaFieldâs extraordinarily high test scores testify to her unwavering commitment to inspire her students to strive for their full potential.
<p style="text-align:center;"><strong>Order Pre-Sale copies starting May 1, 2012!</strong></p>
<a href="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/living-the-lessons_page_1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-638" title="Living the Lessons" src="http://redarrowmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/living-the-lessons_page_1.jpg?w=200" alt="" width="200" height="300" /></a>
<p style="text-align:center;"><strong>Red Arrow's Cast in this project:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:center;"><a title="Allison Armerding" href="http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/2012/04/02/allison-armerding/">Allison Armerding</a>--content editor</p>
<p style="text-align:center;"><a href="http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/2012/03/23/vanessa-j-chandler/">Vanessa J. Chandler</a>--general manager, editor</p>
<p style="text-align:center;"><a title="Renee Evans" href="http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/2012/03/25/renee-renaissance-evans/">Renee Evans</a>--interior book design &amp; promotional material</p>
<p style="text-align:center;"><a title="Samuel Nudds Design" href="http://samuelnuddsdesign.com/" target="_blank">Samuel Nudds</a>--book cover design &amp; promotional material</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Short Story--&quot;Field of Dreams&quot;</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/books-authors-2/655-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Apr 2012 22:25:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/?page_id=655</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Field of Dreams</strong><a href="http://slingstonemedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/Sara-Rust.jpg"><img class="alignright" title="Sara Rust" src="http://slingstonemedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/Sara-Rust-300x244.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="244" /></a>

<em>by Sara Rust</em>

There was no need to awaken the day or the night in this part of the universe, for time was inconsequential. Â Thus, Invested knew that there must be a reason for the dimming light.

Invested stood in a nondescript field.Â  All around him, the grass swayed across small hills.Â  As the light continued to fade, the edges of the grass blades began to glow an ethereal gold. Unsure whether he had arrived at his destination, he thought it best to double-check his invitation.

Taking it out from his pocket, he saw gold lines taking shape, as if the unseen author was still at work. They glowed like the grass beneath his feet.Â  As he watched the lines emerge, he noticed their surprising addition to the invitation â a map.Â  Studying it, he could make out a path, one depicted by a gold line that faded into variegated colors and twisted through rolling fields. He wondered what the colors might mean, and how to follow the path.

Invested turned his attention back to the field and noticed that a patch of grass before him was now glowing a fanciful red.Â  As soon as he stepped into the glowing grass, a new patch began to glow the same color of the next patch on the map.Â  One step after another, Invested navigated the luminous field over hills and dales and finally found himself at a flat clearing.Â  He couldn't help but laugh at the sight before him.

âIs it shocking?â Papa joked from behind him.

âI should have guessed,â Invested admitted.

Papa nodded.Â  âPerhaps.Â  You do have a knack for solving conundrums.â Smiling, he approached Invested with open arms and embraced him.

âIt's a nice field,â Invested offered as he looked again at the bases, foul lines, and pitcher's mound before him.Â  The grass was intensely green, and the boundary lines were pristinely white.Â  It was the most striking baseball field Invested had ever seen.

âI was hoping you'd like it,â Papa replied, âHow about we try her out?â Without waiting for a response, Papa tossed Invested a perfectly worn baseball glove, and the two headed out to the field.

âYou pitch, Invested.â

Invested began to walk towards the pitcher's mound, then turned to Papa, âWhat am I pitching?â

Smiling, Papa held up his palm, asking for a moment.Â  He walked behind the backstop and picked up a canvas bag.Â  Jogging over to Invested, He handed him the bag, then resumed His position beside home plate.Â  Invested continued on to the pitcher's mound where he dropped the bag and looked over the parameters of the field.Â  Bending down and opening the bag, Invested froze.Â  He'd never seen anything like them.Â  Inside were strange transparent balls, and inside each of them danced little flames of light.Â  They looked especially impressive under the dimming sky. He reached down to pick one up, finding the consistency of the ball to be flexible yet delicate.Â  He wondered if he might pop it by handling it too hard.Â  He looked up at Papa, puzzled.

âI'm ready!â Papa said, swinging the bat with great anticipation.

Invested looked back down at the balls, shaking his head, âUm, Papaâ he paused contemplating what to do, âI think...I think I might break them...whatever they are.â

âThey're sturdier than they feel, Invested. Come on!Â  I'm ready!âÂ  Papa placed his feet intentionally, bending his knees, and finding his balance.

Invested was enchanted by these strange spheres and took little notice of Papa, primed to swing.Â  Papa watched him, and smiled.Â  He finally dropped his bat and stood up straight.

âThey're dreams!â Papa cried out.

âDreams?â Invested rolled one around in his hands. âFascinating.â He studied it with keen interest, observing its colors and texture.

Papa knew Invested would be taken with them, He loved Invested's inquisitive nature.

âInvested?â Papa called again.

Invested finally looked back up at Papa.

âThose areÂ <em>your</em>Â dreams, Invested,â Papa said calmly and grinned, âwhy don't you pitch one to me?â

âOh,â Invested gathered himself again, âright, Papa, right.â It was time to get back in the game.

Papa took His stance, wiggled His hips, and pulled back the bat.

As Invested drew back his arm, he felt the dream firm up, as if preparing for the journey. Just before the ball left his hand, it felt as solid and sure as a baseball.Â  Flying towards home plate, the dream began to grow brighter, and the moment Papa hit it, a great fusion of light and sound burst forth from inside the dream, cascading all around like a dazzling firework.Â  The dream soared high above Invested's head, beyond second base, to the outskirts of the field.Â  And just when he thought it might land, that little dream swooped straight up into the sky again and began to gallivant in all directions over the field, flying up and down and circling around.Â  It was quite content to remain in flight.

âThey like to fly,â Papa explained.

Invested watched the dream hurling to and fro around the field, in all its fantastic light and color.Â  It was mezmerising.

âPitch me another, Invested!â Papa finally shouted.

With the first dream flying happily overhead, Invested pitched another.Â  Within a few minutes there were nearly twenty dreams flying above, creating a marvelous light show.Â  Invested reached down into the bag and pulled out a sizeable dream, one his hands could barely grip.Â  He wondered how he was going to throw this one to Papa.

âIt's okay,â Papa affirmed, âI'm fond of the big ones, just pitch it!â

Trying not to think too much about the physics of the problem, Invested drew back his arm, balancing the large dream.Â  With a deep breath, he pitched it right over home plate.

The bat hit the dream launching it straight up to join the flock of other dreams now swarming above.Â  Stunning balls of colorful light filled the sky like an animated starry night. At times the dreams would fly in formation then burst forth into solo acrobatic routines.

Invested stood back from the pitcher's mound gazing up at the sky.Â  Papa dropped the bat and walked over towards Invested.Â âBeautiful, isn't it?Â  Your dreams are beautiful.â He mused.

âThey look better in the sky.â Invested remarked.

âIt's a team effort.â Papa placed his hand on Invested's shoulder.

âThere are so many,â Invested shook his head in disbelief at the sight before him.

Papa smirked and patted Invested on the back, âand this is only a small sampling of your dreams, Invested.â

Papa watched Invested try to follow the dreams as they danced about the sky.Â  Moments later, Invested felt something touch his hands. Papa was handing him a large net, like one used to catch butterflies, but a great deal bigger. Invested broke his gaze from the sky to grab the net. He thought he knew what the net must be for, but he gave Papa a questioning look.

Papa raised an eyebrow.Â  His eyes twinkled with adventure. âNow, it's time to catch one.âÂ  Invested looked back up into the sky and over at Papa again.

âPapa, how do you expect me to catch one of those?

âThat's what the net is for.â Papa replied nonchalantly.

Invested looked at the net and back at Papa, and shook his head, âHave you been watching those little guys dashing around up there?Â  Sometimes they're so fast, I can't even see them!â

Papa simply nodded his head in encouragement, âIt's best to wait for them to fly close to the ground.â

Invested meandered out towards the outfield, net in hand.

âInvested, keep your eye on the ball.â Papa winked.

Invested tried to focus on the dreams above as they jetted by.Â  Occasionally they would descend at a lightening speed and swoop past Invested.Â  He could feel the wind swirl around him.

Papa's voice rose,Â âChoose one, Invested, and stare it down!Â  Don't take your eyes off of it!â

Invested looked overhead to see the great speedway of dreams and purposed to find just one he could keep his eye on.Â  In a few moments he found one, a smallish dream with blue flames burning inside. With great concentration, he followed it with his eyes.Â  The more he watched it, the more it seemed to slow down, until finally the little dream stopped, and began heading straight towards him.

âHold your net out, Invested!â Papa cried.

Invested kept his eyes peeled on the dream as it approached him, and lifted the net overhead.Â  Soon the dream gently found its way right into the net, where it settled as if it wanted a nap.Â  Invested looked back at Papa with a surprised smile.

Papa nodded with pride.Â âGreat job, Invested.Â  Executed like a pro.â

Invested walked back to Papa, now with a dream tucked safely in his net.Â  He held out his catch to Papa, unsure what to do next.

Papa looked the dream over with wonder. âIt's a good one, Invested.â

Invested smiled.

Looking Invested straight in the eye, He instructed, âNow, you eat it.â

âI what?â Invested wasn't sure if he'd heard Papa correctly.

âYou eat it, and honestly the quicker the better, before it sneaks off again.â

Invested wrinkled his brow as he slowly placed his hand inside the net to capture the dream.Â  Once he had it balanced in his hand, he dropped the net and held the dream with both hands. It felt different.Â  It wasn't like the jelly-ball it had been in the bag or the baseball it had been in his pitching hand.Â  It felt soft, like a peach, and tingled with life. Invested looked up at Papa.

Papa shrugged his shoulders, âI have that effect.â

Invested drew the dream towards his nose and sniffed.Â  It smelled sweet and expectant.Â  He sighed and at last took a bite.

He could feel the life that tingled within the dream flow down his throat and finally reside in his belly.Â  It was a strange sensation, to eat a dream, to feel it begin to stir life within him.Â  It was as if the dream itself was hosting a rally within to win the allegiance of his spirit, mind, soul, and body.Â  Things were happening inside him, and all he could explain was that he felt more alive than before he took the bite.

Papa was enthralled. He loved moments like these, seeing the ones He loved enjoying the wonders of the Kingdom.

âAm I to eat it all, Papa?â Invested looked at Papa wondering if the lesson had come to an end.

Papa smiled and looked at the dream Invested held and then up into the sky full of dancing dreams,Â  âEat as much as you like.Â  Eat much or eat little.Â  All I ask is that you enjoy the feast.â

Invested took account of his settings.Â  How marvelous and odd to be eating a dream before Papa under a sky illuminated by dreams.

âYou wonder what is the meaning of all of this, don't you?â Papa asked.

Invested nodded, dream still in hand, now beginning to drip an iridescent juice down his fingers.

âBut the truth is,â Papa said with a grin, âyou are far too observant and clever for me to simply explain this mystery.Â  Tell me what you have seen.â

And although it would have been easy for Papa to unravel the tale, Invested admitted he desired a go at it.Â  His eyes searched the landscape while his mind recalled the experience.Â  Soon something began to stand out to Invested as significant.

âThe dreams,â Invested began, âall came from you.Â  You handed me the bag full of dreams.â

Papa grinned. âThe capacity to dream, the tendency to dream, the propensity to dream for certain things, true.Â  I gave that to you.Â  But the bag was filled with your own dreams, things birthed in your own heart, in your own mind.Â  I just have pleasure in hanging on to them all.â

Invested nodded with understanding.Â  âI had a bag full of dreams, they all had potential, all teemed with light.Â  But something changed when I pitched them to you.â

âSomething remarkable happens when you pick up a dream, turn your eyes towards Me, and then offer Me the dream.Â  Did you notice how the dream changed, Invested?â

âIt firmed up.Â  It began to take shape.â Invested answered.

âEven the loftiest dreams, sense possibility when directed at Me. For with Me all things are possible.Â  Dreams know this.Â  When you begin to pitch, they begin to prepare themselves to transfer from the realm of imagination to possibility.â

Invested peered overhead again to watch the dreams flying above.Â  He nodded his head towards the sky, âThose then, those are dreams that have become possible, is that right?â

âMore than possible. Alive.Â  Fused with purpose, power, and longevity. Released to dazzle all who set their eyes on them.Â  A dream touched by my hand becomes a vessel to expand my kingdom.Â  They take flight because they are so full of life.Â  And there they wait,â Papa directed his vision towards the sky, âin this field of dreams, for one who might see them, one who might catch them, one who might eat them and let them come to fruition. That, Invested, is their greatest desire.â

Papa closed his eyes, âI wish you could see it, Invested.Â  I wish you could see the sight of the field full of all of the dreams of man.Â  No dream is ever lost, you see.Â  When they come to me, they reside together up there, and so they have since man first dreamed.Â  How remarkable the sight when one comes and catches an ancient dream, which like fine wine has been soaring above throughout the ages with ever increasing expectancy. For to dream is to invest, not only that you might carry a dream, but that others might carry one of yours in a day or a year a generation or so.Â  I've even seen dreams merge and multiply up there. It's simply astonishing.â

Invested stood still as Papa grew silent.Â  He looked up into the sky as his ears began to tune in only to the majestic sound of the flying dreams. If he closed his eyes he might convince himself he was beginning to fly, and so Invested did, as he lost himself in the sound.Â  Papa watched him joyously.Â  He quietly approached Invested and gently placed his hand on Investedâs shoulder.Â  The wind around them increased as Papa, for a moment, unveiled the sound of the dreams of all men from all time to the ears of this beloved son.Â  In that spectacular moment Invested could hear the sound of a kingdom â of voices, and songs, and movement and abundant life dictated solely by the wind above.Â  About the time that Invested thought the sound might crush him, Papa removed his hand and took a step back.

âYou have invested in my kingdom,â Papa spoke at last. âYour dreams are good, and not one has been lost.Â  You have a good arm and pitch well.Â  I want to invite you again, Invested, to throw me a new dream or find a dream you might like to taste, to set your eyes on it, and catch it.Â  Whatever delights you.Â  There is no failure here.Â  For the dreams of man cannot shift my goodness or my love. I am faithful to complete the good work I started in you and in this world.Â  So when I invite you to dream, I invite you to play.Â  Do you see?Â  It is not a test.Â  It's an invitation, simply to do something with me.â

Invested stood drinking in this fresh freedom.

Papa took a deep breath.Â  He picked up Invested's glove that was resting on the ground beside them.Â  âPlay with me?â He asked as He offered Invested the glove again.

Invested was standing with his hands on his hips gazing up again into the bountiful sky of dreams.Â  He looked down at the glove, and up at Papa.

âI'd like that,â he said simply reaching for the glove.Â  By the time Invested reached the pitcher's mound again, the canvas bag that had previously been emptied, was full of dreams again.

Throughout the kingdom the crack of the bat and the whirl of dreams could be heard as Invested pitched and Papa launched dream upon dream high above the field into the realms of possibility and hope and life.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>climbing</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/2012/04/06/benjamin-goodpasture/168771_751310800268_29707721_41007113_1853557_n/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 11 Apr 2012 23:40:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>benjamingoodpasture</dc:creator>

	<item>
		<title>Welcome</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/2012/03/19/hello-world/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Mar 2012 03:55:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://redarrowmedia.wordpress.com/?p=1</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Red Arrow Media is a company of media professionals. From the first typed word to the final designed form ready for print, we offer authors a self-service bar full of menu options to compose, produce, print and distribute their work of art.

We specialize in helping new "budding" authors as well as season writers find their unique voice, write and edit their works, and create an aesthetically pleasing interior and exterior design. We also serve as a "middleman" to a plethora of other media services from printing &amp; distribution to bookselling, website development, publicity campaigns, photography and video production.

Since our staff is rather cosmopolitan and comprised of various nationalities (English, Australian, and North American to be specific), we each bring a world of varied experience to the table. We uniteÂ in our desire to create, produce and distribute excellent literary text and various forms of media across the globe. Our vision is to grow and expand into a media company that not only produces literature, but also photographic journals and video documentaries that keep our audiences apprised of current social trends and social justice issues.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-03-19 03:55:03</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-03-19 03:55:03</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>hello-world</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>trash</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
		<title>Embracing Pain</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/2011/08/17/embracing-pain/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Aug 2011 02:45:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://slingstonemedia.com/?p=346</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://slingstonemedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Article-Photo-1.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-420" title="Vanessa Chandler" src="http://slingstonemedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Article-Photo-1-172x300.jpg" alt="" width="172" height="300" /></a>Embracing pain can be excruciatingâ¦but necessary.

Not long ago, I sat with a male friend over coffee. âHow are you?â I asked, expecting his usual answer, âI am great!â But instead, he looked into my eyes and I noticed that his were bloodshot.

He didnât whine or cry, but he said in the matter-of-fact tone that is his personality, âI am in pain.â He had unconsciously placed his hand near his heart.

<em>This ought to be good,Â </em>I thought. <em>A guy being completely real with his emotions.</em>Â I settled in for a deep and interesting conversation.

âWhatâs going on?â I had no idea what he would say in response. He is often difficult to read because (as he has admitted to me), he is afraid of intimacy.

âI am lonelyâ¦itâs like Iâm feeling it for the first time.â

âThis is good,â I said, smiling. âThis is very good because it shows you are alive.â

âIâve been waking up in the middle of the nightâ¦and just sobbing,â he said, his eyes begging for some sense of remorse or compassion from me. I gave him none. I was ecstatic. The man who had been afraid of intimacy was experiencing pain from its lack. This was a very good sign.

âI donât think that you can ever come to a place of accepting and needing intimacy unless you first experience its lack. Since youâve been afraid in the past, the pain of the lack of intimacy in your life is the only thing that will help it become valuable enough to you so that you appreciate it when the right woman comes into your life.â

âYou are so right, but thatâs not what I want to hear!â He said, laughing forcefully with a look that said, âYou just slapped me in the face!â

Little did I know that I spoke words of truth I would be experiencing soon after. So many times in my life, I have let my addictions (however innocent or small), my fascination with men (or day-dreaming about them), or even work or performance fill the void of intimacy in my life. But when youâve stripped away all the excess (as I have done recently) and nothingâs there to fill the void, it can be very, very painful. You realize for the first time in a very long time, âI am lonely.â

Yesterday, one of the young gentlemen in my âhow to be a gentlemanâ class came up to me afterward.

âI have a question about what weâve been talking about in this class,â he said, shuffling his feet in nervousness.

âSure,â I volunteered, attempting to make him feel comfortable.

âWell,â he said looking at me, and then the tears came. âThere was this girl. I thought she was âthe one,â but boy was I wrong. And Iâve had trouble trusting women since then.â

Pain. Pure, unsolicited pain. He didnât ask for the pain, but it was necessary to embrace it so that he could overcome it and eventually trust women again.

Pain is necessary. If we donât want our hearts to be masked by experiences that dilute our loneliness.Â Loneliness is necessaryâ¦if we want our hearts to be fully alive.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Women and Strength: A Curse or a Virtue?</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/2011/08/23/women-strength-curse-virtue/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 23 Aug 2011 23:11:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://slingstonemedia.com/?p=424</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align:left;" align="center"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style:italic;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style:normal;"><a href="http://slingstonemedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Vanessa-Chandler1.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-426" title="Vanessa Chandler" src="http://slingstonemedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Vanessa-Chandler1-300x288.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="288" /></a>by <em>Vanessa J. Chandler</em></span></span></p>
Not too many years ago, I would cringe when someone referred to me as âsingle.â I have now passed the thirty-year mark, surprisingly with satisfaction. However, when I look around at other women that have been labeled âsingle,â I feel my heart grieve. In their eyes, I see the question I have long asked of myself, <em>Has my desire to be strong become a curse ofÂ âsinglehoodâ?</em>Â Single and strong and independent seem to be synonymous. Whatâs wrong with strong and independent? Nothing. Except that in the context of singlehood it has appeared to inhibit romantic relationships.

You might ask, <em>What do you mean?</em> I recently had a young man complain that it is difficult to ask women out because they are âso strong and independent,â and because they donât seem to âneedâ men.

âThey put off that they are âall thatâ,â this young man said to me in frustration. His comment stung my heart. I did not have an opportunity to respond to him at the time (he was across the table in a large group of people), but I wondered at his words for several days.

His comment directed my imagination to a scene in the movie <em>Gladiator</em>. Princess Lucilla, the sister of Commodus, the immature and tyrannical Roman emperor, visits Maximus in prison after he has returned to Rome. Once the commander of the Roman Army, he is now a slave, forced to fight for the pleasure of the âcrowd.â Lucilla and Maximus devise a plan to overthrow Commodusâ¦and Maximus admonishes her to be strong. Her response is shocking, but honestly vulnerable. After all she has doneâto save her sonâs life behind the back of the her twisted brother Commodus, to lead the Roman people in the midst of personal terror, and to plea with the Senate while placating her brother, tears fall down her face and she says to Maximus, âI am tired of being strong.â

I have been moved countless times by watching that scene because it resonates with me. Through all the pain, the accomplishments, the success and the tragedies of my life, there are moments when I no longer desire to be a single woman, because I am tired, so very tired of being <em>strong</em>. So often, single women, who have had to fight through life, taking care of themselves and striving to make something of themselves, have been forced to become (or at least appear) strong out of <em>necessity</em>. Who has been there to fight for us? No one. Who has taken care of us? No one. Who do we rely on when pain causes tears to stream down our faces as we lie in bed at night? <em>No oneâ¦.Â </em>Life has forced us to become strong.

Now let me clarify, particularly for Christians, that I am <em>not</em> suggesting that God does not provide, protect and lead us. I apologize to those who will be offended, but I will not give you a patronizing Christian answer. I am speaking on a tangible level. Physically speaking, single women often reach out their arms, and feel utterlyâ¦<em>alone</em>. Donât believe me? Ask an honest woman. Look into her eyes. You will see her loneliness.

At times, rather than being a responsible, successful, and even beautiful woman, I would prefer to curl up in the arms of my loving Father, safe and secure. I would forgetâfor a momentâthat everything feels like itâs in my own hands and that if I simply lose perspective, I will lose <em>everything</em>. I would forget trying to prove myself to others or even live up to my own expectations. I would not worry about having to appear âemotionally stableâ and âmature.â I would not fuss over whether or not Iâm wearing the right clothes (lest I be too sexy or too frumpy). I would not try to âhold it all together so I donât break.â I would forget that I amâ¦<em>alone</em>.

Letâs go back to the young manâs comment that I referenced in the first paragraph. When I hear a man complain that women are âtoo strong and independent,â I cannot help but grieve. I think to myself, <em>He doesnât understand. </em>We have had to build walls to survive. Sometimes, those walls keep others out, but thatâs never been our intention. Thatâs why we need men to pursue us and tear down the walls we have built to protect ourselves.

Our Western culture has survived several pendulum swings in regard to human behavior, and what is acceptable in society. Fifty years ago, women rebelled against being placed in a box of femininity. From burning our bras to joining the military, our actions, have taught men to âleave women aloneâ because âthey can do it themselves.â Women wanted the opportunity to <em>feel </em>equal to men. Thankfully, both sexes are finally realizing that our differences are what make us compatible, what cause us to be attracted to each other, and to fit together, like a glove on a hand. But because women confused men on what <em>is</em> and <em>is not</em> acceptable, we have essentially caused men to stop the process of pursuit. Without pursuit, a woman is locked in her tower without a rescuer, and forced to be strong out of necessity. As John Eldredge writes in <em>Wild at Heart</em>:
<p style="padding-left:30px;">He tears down the walls of the tower that has held her with his words and with his actions. He speaks to her heartâs deepest question in a thousand ways. <em>Yes, you are lovely. Yes, there is one who will fight for you. </em>But because most men have not yet fought the battle, most women are still in the tower. <a title="" href="#_edn1">[1]</a></p>
Thus, in our culture, men and women are disconnected. Women are afraid to let men inside to be strong <em>for</em> them, and men donât know how to get past the walls that women have built. And all around me, I watch successful, brilliant and beautiful women weep (together, but more often alone) that men are âintimidatedâ by them, or that they are âtoo much,â that men canât work through âissuesâ before running awayâ¦

What can we do about this?

I donât have the answerâonly speculation. Women, do we dare open the door to our soul when it doesnât feel safe? Men, can you push past a womanâs walls into the tenderness of her heart? We both want the same thingâto be fully <em>known</em> and completely <em>loved</em>. I thinkâno, I knowâitâs time for the disconnect to end. My one last piece of advice (and then I will let you ponder), whatever you choose to do, <em>donât settle</em> because you are too afraid to take a risk.

Single women, and single men, I challenge you (as I challenge myself) what are you going to do in order to break down the walls of âsinglehoodâ?
<div>

<hr align="left" size="1" width="33%" />

<div>

<a title="" href="#_ednref1">[1]</a> John Eldredge, <em>Wild at Heart</em> (Nashville: Thomas Nelson, 2001), 187.

</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_author_email>hislovecompels@yahoo.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP></wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2011-11-01 10:55:00</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2011-11-01 17:55:00</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I am reading this as a strong, confident, happily married woman and as I read, I have tears streaming down my face.  I have been praying for my generation for years, as I have seen every bit of what you wrote to be true.  I personally have single friends over whom I have been interceding for years because I have felt the Father's heart for and towards them.  Our generation has so many passionate and strong single men and women who have not been able to find each other because of what you said, because of the previous generation's fight for equality.  It has left our men questioning if their intuition and passionate drive to pursue a woman is right or wrong and it has left our women questioning if it is good and right to be strong and yet at the same time desire to not only be pursued but to also be captured.  My husband and I married in the beginning of my journey to being a strong, powerful woman and because of his confidence in who he is, he did not become insecure as I realized my strength and we are now a "strong, powerful couple".   During my journey to strength, I questioned many times, if I, as a married woman would ever be able to be strong and powerful because in the "happy" marriages that I had grown up around, the women had to be "needy"or "weak" for it to work.  I realized that I had to trust that if God was calling me to stand and be powerful it was not going to destroy my marriage but only make it more intimate and passionate and that that was going to be the only way that either of us would be able to walk out our "destiny" as a married couple and also our own each "individual destinies".  This is a topic about which I have been and will continue to be most passionate, until I see our generation truly set free...Thank you for sharing your heart and continuing to challenge this mind set.]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>To Be or Not to Beâ¦a Writer?</title>
		<link>http://redarrowmedia.com/2012/03/26/bea-writer/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 26 Mar 2012 17:40:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>nessajoy</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://slingstonemedia.com/?p=439</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align:left;" align="center"><strong>To Be or Not to Beâ¦a Writer?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center">(<em>or</em>Â should I say, âTo Attempt or Not Attempt to Trump Shakespeare?â)</p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center"><em>by Vanessa Chandler</em></p>
<p style="text-align:left;" align="center"><a href="http://slingstonemedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/MG_5422.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-441" title="Journal" src="http://slingstonemedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/MG_5422-300x200.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="200" /></a></p>
I suppose you might be wondering whether or not you should leak your disjointed thoughts onto paper, though the thoughts may resemble a can of red paint that tips over and spreads far and wide without any discernable shape. Possibly, you are questioning, <em>Am I a genuine writer? Maybe Iâm just like everybody else who wants to write a bookâ¦</em>

Let me share a few scenes from my own writing journey, and hopefully you will be encouraged to understand that if you are passionate about the written word, you are indeed a writer.

I wrote my first childrenâs story at six years of age, and my first novel at eleven. My mother still has the hand-written (and hand-decorated) copy hidden somewhere in her dusty attic. Of course the heroine of the novel was a princess. The hero? Take a guessâa prince. Everything about it was clichÃ©, but it stemmed from the heart of a little girl who believed in two things: the art of story, and romance. Some say that writing is a naturally borne trait. Others declare that it is an art that can be learned with ample time and practice, and that if one possesses desire, that person can become proficient. I cannot say I know the answer.

What I <em>do</em> know is about myself. I imagined I was a beautiful girl in the midst of a noble tale as early as three years of age (my memory was triggered through my motherâs photographs of me twirling around in a white dress, singing magical songs in the garden). It was as if I innately knew that life was a giant story to be lived out, and that it was sometimes Utopian and sometimes cataclysmic. For me, there was no such thing as love without tragedy, evil without the conquering good, or even a saint who is inexorably punished out of fear, like Hester Prynne of Hawthorneâs <em>The Scarlet Letter</em>. Vivid images ran through my mind like scenes from a storyboard. The concept of Story was, without question, an integral part of my life. I felt that if I was not living within something greater, life was black and white, without color or passion.

If I may be so bold (as an ever-learning professional) to share my thoughts, I would first state that the art of true writing flows from that which lies within. In other words, it is not forced. It stems from the heart. It is an expression of the authorâs thoughts, dreams, wonder, and philosophical questions . . . spilled out onto paper in hopes that someone else might be moved into action to overcome the British slave trade like William Wilberforce, inspired to fall in love like Romeo, or drop to his knees and repent of evil like the Apostle Paul . . . you name it.

Every so often, those that come to me for help with writing believe that if they just lock themselves away and âget the job done,â theyâll arrive at a beautifully polished manuscript. Yes, writing is work. Writing is so much work, and so frustrating at times that you will want to pull your hair out and simply give up. However, before you even enter the stage of serious writing and then editing (which is where you will say time and time again, âCan I just be <em>done</em>?â), you must first <em>live</em>. You cannot paint a masterpiece with words unless you <em>feel</em> something inside that drives you so fiercely to communicate it to the world that âdeath do you part!â âFeeling first takes form within you,â says Dwight V. Swain in <em>Techniques of the Selling Writer</em>, âIf you havenât got a feeling, you canât write about it, let alone arouse it in somebody else.â <a title="" href="#_edn1">[1]</a> To not pursue life or feeling in abundance is death to a writer. Emotion, and allowing oneself to revel in its depth is vital in order to unearth a universal human experience (meaning the authorâs prototype of the grander scheme of life) to pass on to the reader.
<p style="padding-left:30px;">To be a writer, a creative person, you must retain your ability to react uniquely. Your feelings must remain your own. The day you mute yourself, or moderate yourself, or repress your proneness to get excited or ecstatic or angry or emotionally involved . . . that day, you die as a writer. <a title="" href="#_edn2">[2]</a></p>
Creative writers constantly imagine a myriad of make believe scenarios. It may be more work for you to develop fantastical situations, especially if you are more left-brained. But keep in mind that when people read, they want to <em>experience</em>. Take away the universal connection between author and reader and youâve lost the reader by page two. No one wants to read a good idea without you <em>showing</em> the reader <em>how</em> that idea plays out. They want to encounter something new that engages their senses, even if they are merely reading a book like (letâs give it a make believe title) <em>How to Cultivate Healthy Relationships</em>. Regardless of genre, readers want to be absorbed in something, and the best mode or form to do that is through the Art of Story.

Leave a story out, and youâve left out the practical understanding of Jesusâ thoughts in the New Testament. âHow?â You might say. Jesus used the simple parable, the Art of Story, to teach spiritual principals that were difficult to understand. Submit fact without motivating emotion, and you have a doctoral thesis that is stowed away in the libraries of time, and never picked up outside of Academia. Despite your differing personality, the universal experience is something every author can provide since you are the only one in the world to live within your perspective. Donât write what others say they want . . . write from who you are, from the love, tragedy, emotion, anger, hopelessness, and exuberance youâve felt in the varied circumstances of your life, and you will captivate them, despite their initial protest.

âI donât <em>feel</em> that passionately,â you might say. You may not be a touchy-feeling person, but until you take the passion you have for life and translate it into a desire and drive to study the <em>craft</em> of writing and the Art of Story, you will most likely give up just after beginning the writing process. C.S. Lewisâs advice in a letter to Arthur Greeves acknowledges this truth:
<p style="padding-left:30px;">I am sure that some are born to write as trees are born to bear leaves: for these, writing is a necessary mode of their own development. If the impulse to write survives the hope of success, then one is among these. If not, then the impulse was at best only pardonable vanity, and it will certainly disappear when the hope is withdrawn.</p>
Here you might complain in self-pity (as we all sometimes do), âWell, how do I cultivate that innate desire to communicate?â Recently, I reminisced in wonder when I pulled out an email from eight years ago that I had meticulously saved for reference (and carelessly forgot). My mother wrote to me about a published writer she had met, and provided his contact details. At the time, I was taking my first baby steps toward writing through developing stories for an AIDS prevention magazine for children. I was far from my final goal, which was to write a novel. Of course, I didnât follow up with the contact, and I forgot the authorâs name. When I reread the email, while going through some of my old short stories, I realized that the man my mother had mentioned is someone weâve contracted to write for Slingstone Media, the new publishing company my business partner and I have opened. When I reread the authorâs name, I began to laugh . . . In a mere eight years, I have gone from being an English teacher who wrote short stories and poems, to a freelance writer and editor for private clients, to a writer and editor for publishing companies, to writing my first novel, to starting my own publishing company! When put in perspective, I have accomplished a great deal. How is that possible?

It began with a thought. One thought as I walked on a treadmill in a gym while watching the Olympics. <em>Olympic athletes train hard. They sacrifice everything for their dream. They get up at the crack of dawn and push their bodies to the limits. And they donât give up pushing themselves until theyâve competed and at least attempted to win.</em> <em>I wish I had something to sacrifice for like thatâ¦</em>

<em><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style:normal;">And then I knew. I already had that âone thing.â <em>My dream of writing a novel. </em>Up until that point, I constantly talked about my novel, but only worked on it when I felt âinspiredâ (my excuse was that the philosopher Plato said we must wait for inspiration that comes from above . . . so, I had been waiting, and waiting, and waiting).</span></em>

When I encountered the truth of my predicament, I made a conscious effort to work extra hours at the library night after night to make progress. Then, I forced myself to be courageous enough to show my text to a few peopleâone of whom was a small-time producer in Santa Barbaraâthe luxurious beachfront area above L.A. (where in my mind, everything related to media would âhappenâ for me). The presentation of my dream to the producer caused him to offer me a job, which led me to move to Santa Barbara. Santa Barbara opened up a world of new clients, which in turn led me to working as a freelancer for three different publishing companies, and also provided opportunity to meet private clients. One of these clients paid me so well that I went to Europe for a monthâjust so I could tread the same soil that my make-believe characters did in the giant adventure story within my novel. Interestingly enough, this client is also now our first published author through Slingstone Media. The ardent pursuit of my novel led me to contract a literary agent, who encouraged me to actually finish the book (a difficult task for all of us). There I stand. I have finished my novel and it will be released soon. Meanwhile, I have helped countless others reach their dream through Slingstoneâthe first being the private client who invested in my world travels.

That being said, I believe that no matter how difficult you <em>feel</em> writing may be, chipping away at it and learning its craft will carry you to your dream as water carries a wind-blown blossom from a tree. Paulo Coelho, author of <em>The Alchemist</em> says, âWhen a person really desires something, all the universe conspires to help that person realize his dream.â <a title="" href="#_edn3">[3]</a><em> </em>My journey has been long-suffering. There was a particular week as a freelancer when several projects were canceled due to the economy. I suffered. I had no money for groceries. But somehow (as it always happens), a friend knew of my need without me saying a word, and gave me one hundred dollars. Your journey may be more difficult and painstaking than you think itâs worth. That doesnât give you an excuse to evade your dream.

Finally, in case I have not already inspired you, let me give you the core values a writer <em>must</em> live by, and then I will leave you in peace (or in turmoil of thought).
<ol>
	<li>Never, ever give up. Rejection is a common occurrence in this industry. Take the rejection as a learning experience. Revise, and revise again! âThese are the times that wring a writerâs soul. To know you can do it, and yet fail . . . however brutal the pain of failing, you never <em>really</em> fail at something until you stop trying.â <a title="" href="#_edn4">[4]</a></li>
	<li>Believe not only in yourself, but also in your writing. As Marjorie Holmes says, âEvery talent . . . must be backed up by a burning belief in your own ability.â <a title="" href="#_edn5">[5]</a></li>
	<li>Donât take naysayers comments personally. There will always be someone (and sometimes publishing houses) that doesnât appreciate your voice.</li>
	<li>Donât cheat yourself or your audience. Practice, rework your text, and rewrite as many times as it takes until it becomes <em>excellent</em>.</li>
	<li>Get over yourself and your talent. As Robert McKee shares in <em>Story</em>, âWhen talented people write well, it is generally for this reason: theyâre moved by a desire to touch the audience.â <a title="" href="#_edn6">[6]</a></li>
	<li>Solicit help from trustworthy experts and friends. âAn honest answer is like a kiss on the lipsâ (Proverbs 24:26).</li>
</ol>
<div>

<hr align="left" size="1" width="33%" />

<div>

<a title="" href="#_ednref1">[1]</a> Dwight V. Swain, <em>Techniques of the Selling Writer</em> (Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 1965),?.

</div>
<div>

<a title="" href="#_ednref2">[2]</a> Dwight V. Swain, <em>Techniques </em>. . ., 13-14.

</div>
<div>

<a title="" href="#_ednref3">[3]</a> Paulo Coelho, <em>The Alchemist</em> (New York: HarperCollins, 1996), 121.

</div>
<div>

<a title="" href="#_ednref4">[4]</a> Marjorie Holms, âFormula for Success,â <em>The Writer</em>, November 1982, 9-11, 23.

</div>
<div>

<a title="" href="#_ednref5">[5]</a> Ibid.

</div>
<div>

<a title="" href="#_ednref6">[6]</a> Robert McKee, <em>Story: Substance, Structure, Style, and the Principles of Screenwriting</em> (New York: HarperCollins, 1997), 7.

</div>
